item.title: Netting
item.description:
multiple payments are aggregated together to make one payment. This is done for various reasons but the main one is to reduce transaction costs. Eg For example, all payments going from RMB to SBSA today could be netted to create one payment. In MX there are netting keys that define the aggregation rules, the main netting keys that the recons team works with are: corporate actions e.g Issuer, value date, account, entity, flow type, security) Payment and funding on netted. The resultant flow must be settled before the underlying flows can be released for payment events if reported on net. IRD legs e.g. origin producer, currency, portfolio, date, settlement metho Payment and funding on gross flows. Source [1]
If netting key reference 23 is applied, funding is generated on the netted result; otherwise, funding is generated on the individual underlying deliverables (DLVs). Once a DLV reaches NetSettled or Settled status, Murex automatically generates the funding, sends a message to Chameleon, and receives the corresponding funding response.

item.title: NII
item.description: Net Interest Income (NII) is the difference between interest earned on a bank’s interest-bearing assets (like loans, bonds, placements) and the interest paid on its interest-bearing liabilities (like deposits, borrowings, repos).It’s the core earnings from the bank’s maturity transformation activity — essentially how much it earns from lending and investing compared to what it pays to fund those activities.That 4.4 is the net interest income, which feeds into the P&L.NII reflects how interest rate risk and funding strategy impact profitability. Treasury and ALM desks manage NII over time by controlling:NII is one of the two main IRRBB metrics:So, ALM simulations often produce: Base NII projection NII under rate up/down shocks ΔNII (difference) to measure risk exposure. Business units see NII as their margin after internal funding:Treasury earns NII too — the spread between internal FTP inflows/outflows and external market funding costs.

item.title: Residual Cash Funding
item.description:
Treasury funds this via short-term repos, commercial paper, or interbank borrowing Residual funding cost influences Treasury’s liquidity buffer and Net Interest Income (NII)
Final sweep[1] at end of day. Captures any remaining cash balances not already funded.
Always priced at the Overnight FTP rate (repo/OIS). Typically covers realised P&L and timing mismatches.
FX Desk realises ZAR 5 m profit today.
At EOD, system sweeps it into GTSY as an overnight deposit. Desk earns FTP (O/N) until it redeploys the cash. → Ensures no stray balances remain in portfolios. Residual Funding → runs last at EOD to sweep any leftovers.
→ Cash-Based Funding
Source [2] Each portfolio Dedicated funding account
Set up per currency in Chameleon (TS Call Account) Maintains balance of the funds Flowing from and into the portfolio – i.e. portfolio funding balance. All settlements on the portfolio (internal and external) must be affected through this TS account.
A portfolio is charged / paid Overnight funding interest for the EOD ZAR balance on its TS account (foreign currency balances are not charge interest),
With the contra funding benefit / cost posted to the central GTSY funding portfolio. Funding interest is accrued throughout the month in Chameleon and capitalized at the end of each month.

item.title: Position Funding
item.description:
Treasury uses behavioral modeling (decay rates, duration) Common in IRRBB and Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR) management FTP rate may include an embedded Liquidity Premium End-of-day batch process. Funds open positions where no clear contractual maturity exists equities, revolving loans, unsettled capital Treasury applies a behavioural tenor (e.g. 1M, 3M) to approximate how long the position ties up liquidity.
Rolled daily, but priced at the behavioural FTP Curve.
Equities Desk holds R 200 m of listed shares. That R200 m still required cash to buy the shares → Treasury provided it. But equities have no maturity date. Treasury assumes they behave like 1M rolling funding. At EOD, system books: Internal funding loan: R200m at . Asset: R 200 m equities. Liability: R 200 m behavioural funding loan. → Desk only shows profit if equity returns is greater than cost of rolling 1M funding. Position Funding → runs at EOD to capture behavioural positions.

item.title: Types of Funding
item.description:
Source[1]
RMB is transitioning from cash-based TS Account's (Chameleon) to a trade-based funding model in Murex.
Under the new framework, all portfolios are fully funded by Group Treasury (GTSY) using three processes
Trade Funding
Position Funding
Residual Funding
These methods ensure that every trading and banking position is funded at the correct cost, using the appropriate FTP curve.
AKA Trade Funding / Term Funding
AKA Behavioural Funding
AKA Overnight Sweep Trade Funding → runs in real time as trades are booked. Position Funding → runs at EOD to capture behavioural positions. Residual Funding → runs last at EOD to sweep any leftovers. At the end of each day, all portfolios are fully funded and all liquidity sits with Treasury.Even if the desk “already has the asset”: To buy an asset, you needed cash → Treasury provided it. That cash has a cost → reflected via an FTP loan. Without this, desks would appear to make “free” returns, ignoring liquidity cost. Funding ensures true profitability is visible.

item.title: Breakage
item.description: In treasury and financial markets, breakage refers to the loss, cost, or gain incurred when a contract, funding arrangement, or hedge is terminated or altered before its original maturity.Essentially: ⚠️ “Breakage” = the financial impact (positive or negative) from breaking a transaction early. When breakage is due to an early termination of a fixed-rate position:Where: = rate at which original funding/contract was priced = prevailing market rate for the same tenor If ​, the breakage is a loss (you’re losing a better yield) If ​, the breakage may be a gain (you can reinvest at higher yield) Think of breakage like a contract cancellation fee: You agreed to lend or borrow under certain market conditions — if you break that agreement early, one party loses its expected economics, so the other compensates it.

item.description:
True Cost of Money & Proper Allocations FTP is a process: Consolidating bank's funding requirements Results from provisioning of bank's products in central Treasury book
This enables Treasury to efficiently control and manage the bank's funding and Maturity Mismatch Prices funding costs/benefits of a banks products or business lines to establish true profitability of these parts
Source [1] All funds needed for banks requirements (assets) are obtained from deposits (liabilities) from Treasury via an internal loan/deposit or funding transaction
Treasury manages price via Liquidity Premium Curve
Prices these transactions on top of Interbank Swap Rate or Curve
See Funding Curve Diagram Together → FTP Rate
Treasury maintains the different Premiums for different products to indicate their specific impact.
At Minimum, Treasury needs to maintain a positive LP spread between the FTP rate paid by Treasury for funds provided by liability products.
Surplus from the spread allows for the cost of the banks funding and Maturity Mismatch on the financial market to be managed

Repo Desk’s external trades are booked against GTSY portfolios. This allows Treasury to allocate true FTP cost of repo funding back to desks.

item.title: Repo Sweeping
item.description:
Repo sweeping is the centralized mechanism by which all bond long/short positions across RMB’s Trading Desk's are transferred (“swept”) to the Repo Desk's, which acts as the single point of contact with the external repo market.This ensures: Collateral optimisation – the bank sees all eligible securities in one place. Liquidity efficiency – one central desk negotiates repo rates. Risk control – traders don’t face external repo counterparties directly. Transparency – funding costs recorded via FTP and internal mirror trades. Bond Desk agrees to buy R100m SA Government Bond ( settlement). On settlement day, Repo Desk simultaneously: Receives the bond into its custody account. Repos it out to a market counterparty, receiving cash. Uses that cash to pay the seller. Internally:
Repo Desk allocates the bond to the Bonds Desk (mirror entry). Bond Desk shows: Bond asset + Repo loan liability. Repo Desk shows: Internal loan asset + External repo liability. Custody flow (DvP at CSD): Seller → Repo Desk custody → Repo Counterparty (pledge). Cash: Repo Counterparty → Repo Desk → Seller. Bond Desk agrees to sell R50m bond it doesn’t own.
Repo Desk arranges a Reverse Repo with the market: Repo Desk lends cash externally. Market counterparty delivers the bond into Repo Desk custody. Internally: Repo Desk lends the borrowed bond to the Bond Desk (mirror). Bond Desk delivers the bond to the client and receives sale cash. Custody flow (DvP at CSD): Repo Counterparty → Repo Desk custody → Client. Cash: Client → Trading Desk. Market access: Concentrates borrowing/lending activity → better pricing. Collateral management: Avoids desks competing for the same bonds. Operational simplicity: Only one external settlement point (Repo Desk custody account).
FTP consistency: Funding costs (repo rate + liquidity spread) embedded via mirror trades. Repo funding trades are internalised via mirror deals between Repo Desk and Trading Desk.
Repo Desk’s external trades are booked against GTSY portfolios. This allows Treasury to allocate true FTP cost of repo funding back to desks.
Repo Desk custody accounts sit at the CSD / Settlement Agent (e.g., Strate, Euroclear, Clearstream). Trading desks never instruct CSD directly — they only see internal mirror positions. Daily sweeps reconcile all long/short positions into Repo Desk accounts, ensuring: Zero unrecognised cash balances. Central visibility of collateral. Flat trading desks (no external exposures). ✅ Summary:Repo sweeping makes the Repo Desk a central “collateral warehouse”. Trading desks hold market risk, but the Repo Desk holds custody and funding responsibility. All desks are “funded” internally at FTP repo rates, while Repo Desk optimises externally.
